title: Newcastle Jets win first Australia Cup title | Muswellbrook Chronicle
body_text:
Maybe it was the 6432 days between trophies, the grand final heartache at home, all the missed play-offs, the wooden spoons.
Subscribe now for unlimited access.
or signup to continue reading
Maybe it was the ownership, which lay in limbo for seemingly forever, and only resolved with Maverick Sports Partners in between seasons last year.
Maybe it was the coach, former Socceroos representative Mark Milligan, who has now tasted success less than six months into his tenure and who has yet to even preside over an A-League fixture.
Maybe it was the Japanese star, the bloke who Sydney FC rejected, skipper Kosta Grozos, a bandaged-up Thomas Aquilina or the kids, including two aged under 23 who scored extra-time goals off the bench.
Maybe it was the fans - the ones who hopped on a bus at 4:30am that morning and travelled 1000 kilometres just to be there, the ones back at Modus in Merewether or the long-suffering ones watching quietly from home around the Hunter.
Maybe it was the ticket back to Asia, qualifying for next year's Champions League 2 and a winner's cheque of $50,000.
Maybe it was, simply, the sum of all its parts.
Whatever the case, there can be no denying, for the first time in club history, the Newcastle Jets are Australia Cup champions.
It came 17 years after Newcastle's only A-League triumph in 2008, on the back of five straight wins in this year's national knockout tournament and following 120 minutes of highly entertaining football.
However, it was the underdogs, a Victorian-based NPL side born out of Greek heritage and up against full-time professionals, that struck first via Ryan Lethlean's header in the eighth minute.
Max Burgess, a new Jets recruit who later received the Mark Viduka Medal for best on ground, equalised midway through the first half.
A stalemate ensued in the second stanza, leaving scores locked at 1-all and requiring 30 minutes of extra-time.
Who was going to be the game breaker? Enter, Oscar Fryer. In the process of returning after 12 months sidelined with an ACL injury, the 19-year-old substitute produced a memorable moment. A stunning left-foot strike curling into the side netting for a 2-1 advantage.
Send offs in quick succession, Grozos followed by Heidelberg's Johnny Apostolopoulos, did nothing to deter Newcastle's Ben Gibson from sealing the deal five minutes from full-time.
Celebrations were now in full swing. The crowd figure was 10,000.
THE GAMEBREAKER
With an Australia Cup final hanging in the balance at 1-all, Jets coach Mark Milligan called on his bench.
One by one, experienced starters came from the field - Burgess, Lachlan Rose, Kota Mizunuma, Daniel Wilmering.
Entering the fray throughout the second half, all aged 22 or under, were the likes of Gibson, Lachlan Bayliss, Christian Bracco, Alexandro Nunes and, eventual man of the moment, Fryer.
Six minutes into extra-time and Fryer seized his opportunity.
Caught in "no-man's land" near the byline, Fryer cut back inside the penalty box and accelerated away from his Heidelberg defender.
With room to move and an eye for goal, the teenager put 12 months worth of sidelined energy into one special left-foot hit and Newcastle, for the first time, found themselves ahead (2-1).
"Sort of speechless after that one," Fryer told host broadcaster Paramount Plus after full-time.
"I was out for 12 months [ACL] so to come back and win a final, it's a dream come true.
"It's been 12 months of anticipation building up and I let it all out with that left foot, so amazing."
Fryer, a Sydney FC academy product, only made his debut for the Jets recently, a round-of-16 derby with local NPL club Cooks Hill at No.2 Sportsground.
He explained the thought process around that pivotal play.
"I was in no man's land, but once I got him [defender] square I could go either way. Beat him, it happened, created the space and knocked it home," Fryer said.
He also paid tribute to manager Milligan, who has his post-match press conference stormed by celebrating Jets players.
"Millsy's brought a great brand of football to the boys, instilled a hard-work attitude in all the boys that represents the Newcastle community well," Fryer said.
THE HOMEGROWN TALENT
Will Dobson summed it all up pretty simply amid the celebrations.
"Honestly, I've never felt like this," he told host broadcaster Paramount Plus on Saturday night.
Dobson, 18 and born around six months before the Jets last claimed silverware, has climbed up the club ranks since his junior days at Belmont.
He paid tribute to Newcastle's travelling fan base at Lakeside Stadium and also gave a nod to players who paved the way previously wearing red and blue.
"To run over there to those fans, they followed us, two buses came from Newcastle this morning, they left at 430 [am] just to travel here and to see that," Dobson said.
"I was in the stands for 2018, the heartbreak in that final [A-League loss], and to give these guys that feeling is just."
In relation to assessing Dobson's own performance - earning a spot in the starting XI, dangerous touches across the park, helping set up one goal and almost scoring another himself.
"The gaffa [Milligan] has put a lot of confidence in me," he said.
"I started out here tonight and I think I did kind of ok. It's all I want to do - bring energy, play my game and show how good I am."
MARK VIDUKA MEDAL
MAX Burgess, 30, was frozen out of Sydney FC last season.
He arrived at the Newcastle Jets for 2025-2026, having enjoyed a brief stint previously around a decade ago.
Now, he's not only an Australian Cup champion, but also the recipient of the Mark Viduka Medal for being voted best on ground in the knockout final.
"It's really special. I'm sort of lost for words at the moment. The boys and club have really taken me in and I'm really grateful to be part of it. So stoked," Burgess told host broadcaster Paramount Plus.
Burgess netted the all-important equaliser in the 21st minute, a well-timed run inside the box and putting away an assist from Aquilina down the right.
He was replaced midway through the second half, and gave a nod to the younger brigade of high-flying Jets.
"Not just today but this whole cup run, they've won us games and been brave in big moments," Burgess said.
"Especially today, me and Kota [Mizunuma] came off, I was cramping and had nothing left.
"They came on and were brave, positive, as they have been the entire run, so stoked for them."
Burgess feels like leadership and lifestyle have helped him find his feet in Newcastle this campaign.
"I've really focused on processes for me and trying to lead in this group, which I think has brought something out in me," he said.
"Also just trying to work hard and be the best version of myself and just focus on that.
"Life outside football in Newy is amazing - the surf, cafes and people are so friendly. So loving being there."
The starting XI was: James Delianov, Aquilina, Aleksandar Susnjar, Mark Natta, Wilmering, Grozos, Dobson, Burgess, Mizunuma, Rose and Xavier Bortoncello.
Bayliss, Gibson, Nunes, Fryer, Bracco and Lucas Dean Scicluna were the substitutes used.
Eli Adams and Joe Shaughnessy were missing through injury, Max Cooper dropped out late due to illness and Alex Badolato continues at the Under-20 World Cup in Chile.
Celebrations are tipped to continue in Newcastle on Monday, with Jets players appearing with the Australia Cup at Queens Wharf Brewery from 11am to 1pm.
A-League opening round in a fortnight sees an away derby with the Central Coast Mariners (Sunday, October 19).
A-LEAGUE FINALS HOPE AND SHOT AT ASIA
AAP reports: Fresh off a maiden Australia Cup title, Newcastle coach Mark Milligan wants the long-floundering Jets to embrace the expectation of finals, then a shot at Asian football.
The Jets sealed their first trophy in 17 years with a 3-1 victory over Heidelberg United in Saturday night's final at Lakeside Stadium.
They have only played finals once in the past 15 years but former Socceroos captain Milligan believes Newcastle can return to the top six.
"We want to be a team that plays finals football. We want to compete for things. We're trying to build a brand of football that we think will do that," Milligan said.
"We're trying to create a squad in terms of the competitive nature that will do that. We want to be fighting for things. I want our fans to be excited by this.
"Expectation's not a bad thing. I want these players to be driven. I don't want them to feel like just because we've won the Cup we've succeeded, because we're a long way away from succeeding.
"There's still a lot of growth in this group to go. There's a lot of hard work to do, but I'm not going to cap what success looks like for them."
Newcastle have also qualified for next year's Asian Champions League 2 competition.
Milligan, who won the 2015 Asian Cup and had stints in China, Japan, the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia, says Australian football needs to embrace that stage.
"We should all strive to do well, to be a part of and to do well in Asia," he said.
"Especially with my history as well. I played a lot of football through Asia. I have a great appreciation for a lot of countries over there and how they go about their business.
"It's a tough competition, but now I believe it's more rewarding for clubs to want to do well in it.
"As a nation, as a footballing nation, we should want to be a part of it and we should want to do well in it."
Heidelberg, who won $25,000 as runners-up, will prepare for their Australian Championship campaign, which kicks off next week.
But coach John Anastasiadis wouldn't be surprised if some of his players receive late calls from A-League clubs.
"They haven't done themselves any disservice," he said.
"You can get a knock on the door, and I told them football changes every day.
"It can change in a moment, so I'm hoping some of them do get a chance."
Anastasiadis is rated as one of the best coaches outside the A-League Men but was modest on his chances of a move to a higher league.
"It's great to have this success, no doubt it helps," he said.
"But you just wait and see. If it happens, it happens. If it doesn't ... well, we keep going."
